author: The_Domo

description.text:
This is a coaster-sized Flower of Life, a sacred geometrical figure. It's about 5 mm thick and takes approx. 2 hours to print. A nice thing to show off at parties:
"Oh, no thanks I brought my own coaster. That I made. On a 3d printer."

The height of the flower is kind of weird at 4.95mm, and so I sliced it at .2475mm layers to end up with an even 20 layers. That's probably not necessary; I imagine .25mm layers would work fine.  
It took over 2 hours to finish on my Solidoodle 2, mostly due to the complexity of the extruder path.  
Enjoy!  
I uploaded another .stl in which I added a circle to the perimeter and adjusted the height to 5mm.

author: jmidjettesr

description.text:
THIS IS EXPERIMENTAL So, for my first try at python and gcodes, I figured I would play with the Unicorn scripts. After 3 hours, here is the result. This is the plotterize.py script, but with some modifications. The first and biggest one is that you no longer need a servo. The reason is that I'm a money hog and didn't want to spend money on extra stuff to move a pen up and down when the z-axis does the same thing. I have edited this script to move the z-axis up and down instead of moving the servo up and down (You have a z-axis, why not use it?). NOTE: This is the script only. I have yet to design something that will hold a pen (Preferably without having to remove the extruder). FUTURE EDITS:
Try to fix the z speed
Change end print coding
Create more user variables for better interactivity I suggest you look over the plotterize.py before changing anything not mentioned in the instructions.
Note that this is only a edited version of the plotterize script.

Run the plotterize script. Dont change any of the variables from the command line without first reading the plotterize script, so you know what the original values are. Copy and paste the start.gcode text into the beginning of the file you created with the plotterize script. IMPORTANT
At this line:
G92 Z+80 ( ---=== Set Z axis maximum ===--- )
Change 80 to the height you want from the top of your Makerbot to your printer. Ex.
My max height is 108.8. (Say my pen is at the same place as the extruder on the z-axis)
My pad of paper is 10mm high.
108.8-10=98.8
I should change the line to:
G92 Z+98.8 ( ---=== Set Z axis maximum ===--- ) Print

description.text:
Ultraviolet Germicidal light is supposed to remove 98% of germs, think of how many things could live on your sponge and then you clean
your cutting board and knife with it. Just remove the wand from the
stand and wave it over the cleaned cutting board and knife
then put the wand back on the stand the sponge in the sponge holder
and zap that too.

You will need an electric lamp housing with an on off switch in the
cord and an ultraviolet bulb. I am using a GTL3 Germicidal Tube
Lamp - E17 Base - 10.5 Volt for around $8.00 and a lamp socket
and cord with switch from the hardware store for about $12.00. The power supply for this bulb is a class 2. This is printed in pieces and
with minimum support. Update: 3/8/15 I have broken out the parts some will need support others will not. I still have not printed the whole thing yet but now that the parts are done I will start and see where there may be any problems (as I found with the first base print). This is still a work in progress! Update: 3/9/15 I split the sides into one as they are both the same and I split the posts into two because only one will need support. Update: 3/10.15 It's a good thing I am not an engineer, minor flaw with the sides and the base but I fixed it in rev2. Just the top to print and then put it together. Should be ready and (cross my fingers) working by the due
date. Update: 3/14/15 I have revised some more pieces as I finished the printing and put it together and have removed the old information in the STL files and
left the revised.

Simple mounts to add acrylic sides to your Kossel Mini to keep drafts out.  Not a total enclosure.  Still in test but preliminary results show a decrease in warping when printing with a heated print bed.

Printed out with PLA .3 layer height 3 perimeters, but the part is so simple I bet most settings would work.  I happened to have 3 300 x 540 x 2mm acrylic sheet scraps (I needed 4), so I thought this might be a better use.  The mounts are secured to the frame using M3 8mm screws.  There are holes on the top and bottom for M3 6mm screws if you want to use friction to hold the acrylic in place, but be warned that it will scuff and scratch the acrylic.  I keep the panels loose because I am still working on this printer and need to get inside often.  
I printed them on the side to maximize strength.  The rectangular boxes are to support more weight, so I suppose you could use something heavy like glass, but I really didn't test it.

Nike+ data visualizer application, generated as a part of the MakerBot Hackathon, April 6-7, 2013. The application reads your Nike+ exercise data and generates a Customizable Thing containing your data. You can then Customize your Thing to add your name and scale the model to the size you'd like to print. At the moment, we visualize one week of your data. The generated Thing has STLs for printing in a single color (use the STL named 'both') and dualstrusion (merge the 'left' and 'right' STLs). Developers are Robert Carlsen (http://www.thingiverse.com/technophobe), Sune Kaae and Laird Popkin (http://www.thingiverse.com/laird). UPDATE: Source code is released on GitHub here: https://github.com/sunekaae/activity-visualizer. Enjoy! @laird @robertcarlsen @sunekaae

To make your own, go to http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/activity-visualizer. To access it and visualize your own Nike+ Fuel, you need to get your access token, which is done via Nike's developer site; http://developer.nike.com (click console tool and "get my access token"). You just use your normal Nike+ email/password - you don't need a special developer account. Run the application at http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/activity-visualizer , and it'll retrieve your Nike+ data and use it to make a Customizable Thing for you. Then customize the thing to scale it to the size you like, generate the Thing, and print it! Generates both single-color and dualstrusion.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:41703 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=41703

Using the following options: height = 50
cell_radius = 8
honeycomb_radius = 3
floor_thickness = 2

The delrin plunger, while an elegantly simple idea, bothers me a little because of the added drag on the filament. Even more so with the stepper driven mk6 extruder since for me at least there seems to be a pretty fine line between having it tight enough and too tight such that you are losing steps.
Like jstkatz and his http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7037 I didn't like having the 4 screws and springs. I wanted something a little little simpler and could more easily pivot out of the way.
jstkatz's design definitely came out a little more elegant but functionally I think they are pretty similar (except mine uses the mk6 nema 17 motor).

Print the two parts. You shouldn't need support, I added some into the files already. There is now a quick release lever for this extruder ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7449 )
I seem to be having good success with the lever and no spring at all. It looks like an M4x40 bolt would be the right one for use with the lever. Cut the support off the pivot location on the main body (on the lower right).
Cut the support material out of the pivot arm where the bearing mounts.
Clean up as necessary. It may help to run an appropriately sized drill through all of the holes.
Mount the bearing to the pivot arm with an M6 bolt & Nut (or you can print out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11424 )
Mount the pivot arm to the body with an M3 bolt & nut on the bottom and an M4 bolt, nut, washer and spring on the top.
You may need to cut out a little material to fit the M4 nut in there. I'll make slot a little bigger for the next version. Insert the 4 M3 nuts into the provided slots. The one by the idler pivot can be a little fiddly to get in there.
Bolt to the extruder support with 4 M3x12 Bolts. Bolt the stepper, cork gasket & fan mount with 4 M3x12 Bolts. Let me know if I missed anything! Change Log (started on 5/8/11)
5/8/11 Uploaded new idler arm (stl and alibre part) that works with 1.75mm filament (and 3mm)
6/28/11 Scaled the body part so that it doesn't need to be scaled before printing (inches->mm)

This is an spice rack shaped to an arch it is useful because you can hold your items of choice on the shelves and its shape is designed to provide lots of storage room well taking up a small area allowing other appliances to go underneath.
For best print quality print on its back side face down, various models for desired mounting style no need for supports! enjoy!
I asked my wife what she wished she could have on the kitchen counter, her wish became my creation. Hope everyone could use it.
It is a very simple design, I would probably go with Plexiglass for the glass doors.

All you need to have is a large enough print bed. Or you can print them smaller to make them 'kid sized'. Enjoy! #CountertopChallenge Link to food safe PLA: http://www.makergeeks.com/fogrplafi.html NOTE: You will need to make sure the scaling is correct before you print. Flatware box/lid have same ratio as all silverware.
Martini and Wine glasses have same ratio as the inverted holder. Also you should be able to get a screw driver in the corner to attach the holder to the cabinet. Everything was modeled using OpenSCAD and I will put its' source up here once I clean it up some.

A set of three figurines reconstructed from motion capture data of a baseball swing. A cool experiment in collaboration with ZenoLink! Modeled with an OpenSCAD script by placing a sphere at the coordinates of each joint and connecting nodes with the hull command to form the limbs and torso. The sweep of the bat in the third model is formed by the union of the hull of each consecutive pair of bat positions. I think it's a fairly successful way to make a static visualization of an object's motion. Next step might be to replace the simple stick figure with some other character model rigged with the same data.

Printed in hard-to-photograph black PLA on my wood Printrbot Simple. 0.3 mm layers, 3 perimeters, 5% rectilinear infill, and various retraction/temperature settings (experimenting to minimize overhang curling). Temp was a bit too low (190) on the middle model as there are some separating layers. Also my first time using MeshMixer to add semi-manual supports. Awesome.

title: Coffee Monsta! Eats the used coffee grounds in your spent k-cups!

description.text: latest post:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1831661 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Launched this homebrewed k-cup coffee composting tool the beginning of February 2014 (rev40) after about a year of prototyping and getting feedback from friends, family and offices that are using this device in Vermont! April 2017 update REV53 heavy office use tested over 5 months daily with low quality moisture ridden PETG filament before it broke except it takes 1.5h to print (with a small computer fan on just when the top 3 legs are printing no supports) .2mm layer thickness, 90% fill helps stitch layers together... Just printed with transparent PLA with the above settings and it looks like heavy use should be no problem for more than the previous prints 5 months (over 12 cups/day in an office :) ) All you need to use it is a wide mouth mason jar of your choice and just fasten it on the jar where the lid would normally go. After your coffee is done brewing,(and the spent k-cup is cooled down), take the k-cup out and pop it down on the pointed top, give it a half twist one way, then the other, tap a couple times, and the coffee will fall out into the jar and the metal foil will stay on the cup and not in the coffee grounds that can now go in the compost or in the garden! Think of the billions of tons of coffee that could be helping plants grow in the garden! (or a lawn, as with a little rain to help it disperse, it doesn't help the grass or kill it) As you can see from the gallery pictures, there's a lot of design changes to reach this crazy shape, i would posslbly like to make it commercially, except it will likely add to the plastic waste stream and just know that it will lead to mildew that needs to be washed out of the jar every few days or when it fills up, and/or if you are going to put this shape into a remixed commercial product, it will need a dehydration scheme so the grounds don't sit in the bottom of the jar all wet. Fresh dried out PLA filament is the way to go for this print to work best, good luck!

comments.text: For decades I have been trying to come up with an ideal way to slice a banana. "Use a knife!" they say. Well...my parole officer won't allow me to be around knives. "Shoot it with a gun!" Background check...HELLO! I had to resort to carefully attempt to slice those bananas with my bare hands. 99.9% of the time, I would get so frustrated that I just ended up squishing the fruit in my hands and throwing it against the wall in anger. Then, after a fit of banana-induced rage, my parole officer introduced me to this kitchen marvel and my life was changed. No longer consumed by seething anger and animosity towards thick-skinned yellow fruit, I was able to concentrate on my love of theatre and am writing a musical play about two lovers from rival gangs that just try to make it in the world. I think I'll call it South Side Story.

author: Fullnoise

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Fan Upgrade V2

description.text: After releasing my initial upgrade, I came across several issues: the pressure of the shroud was too great for the wee little CPU fan, the large size of the shroud meant it was prone to damage, and the shroud also hit the Printrbot's base when it was homed. This updated version has fixed all of these issues, most notably with a smaller, but stronger fan. This new fan has a higher amount of torque, and can much better handle the pressure created.

comments.text:
the first fan I tried was too strong so I switched to a slower fan, I just noticed it's hardly blowing any air at all as it is unable to overcome the air pressure. I think I need a fan controller or something.
The other problem I keep having seems to be coming from the air blowing only on one side of the extruder. This seems to cause the extruded plastic to not stick when the print head moves left.

author: snape99

description.text:
This is a Tablet/Phone stand designed to fold up flat and be carried in a person's pocket. It doesn't matter which way it is unfolded, as the top and bottom are completely symmetrical. It is a complete redesign of my old (unpublished) stand that had issues. Each part will need to be rotated 90 degrees, if someone could tell me how to get Autodesk Inventor to stop making everything sideways, I would appreciate it. Read instructions for further info, and please tell me if it works! The problem with the old one was that is broke too easily, and it also couldn't hold anything without collapsing.
(EDIT)
I tried this with my Nexus 7, and it doesnt really work that well. I will be updating this when I have the time.

Needed quantity:
Frame: 1
Arm: 2
Backplate: 1
Clip: 1
Peg: 6 (Optional)
The stand is assembled using the supplied pegs, but they are somewhat fragile, so they can be substituted for 1/2in long by 1/8in diameter machine screws. Print at 0.15-0.25mm layer thickness, 0.20mm reccomended, and use touching bed support because the thin parts of the clip and frame are slightly smaller than the flat surfaces.

comments.text: in autodesk inventor, make the parts on the top plane, and most printers will place it correct in the printer

author: joshchretien

title: Test Stripes to calibrate extruder start and stop 0v1

description.text: This is the second version. The older version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7091 This is a simple piece that forces the extruder to start and stop on short strips. If the strips are clean and the exact same length as the control box, the start and stop calibration of the extruder is good! This version has better control of the test stripe so you can tweak it to one pass of the head, and prints out multiple sets of bars, each at a different length. Slightly related to: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8859
Just print and look at your output. Tweak and repeat!

author: Paintballmagic

description.text:
The B'Struder is an entirely new Bowden extruder design. It fits all common stepper motors, and all popular pinch gears. Variants are available for several common tube connections. YOU PICK THE EXTRUDER HARDWARE! All you need is a few M3 screws/nuts, a suitable ~3/8" or ~10mm spring, and three 623 bearings. Unlike most extruder designs, the B'Struder filament path runs entirely through the spring idler arm. This accomplishes two unique things:
1) Makes the filament path alignment very tolerant of different pinch gear diameters
2) Makes tension on the Bowden tube (due to filament pushing force) mildly assist pinch gear grip This requires very specific geometry for the hinge, idler bearing, output fitting, and pinch gear contact point. This is a new design, and feedback is welcome. But it's working great in my Delta so far. I'm running very aggressive retraction settings without any issues. Let me know how it works for you! [UPDATE 11-13-15] Performance has been consistently awesome. I have two of them running with a lot of hours on each. The only real changes I have in the "to do" list are:
1) Widen filament inlet a bit
2) Add more fitting options (eg E3D pushfit insert, M4 tube back to the drive gear for flexibles) -- SEE REMIXES FOR MORE OPTIONS

Print the arm at 0.1mm with >50% infill and good print cooling. PLA should be fine. No supports required if printed "upright" as the STLs are oriented. May require minor cleanup of bearing pockets or filament path with a hobby knife / drill depending on your printer. Stick an M3 nut in the nut pocket, insert a 623 bearing into the bearing slot, and screw a 12-14mm M3 screw into the nut to capture the bearing. Stick two more 623 bearings in the hinge pocket. They should be a snug fit. Print the plate with whatever settings you want as long as it's strong. No supports required. I recommend ABS if you run your motor hot. (I'm using PLA with motor current not maxed out, but that's risky.) For NEMA 17 motors, align the hinge pivot hole with the motor bolt pattern. For smaller or geared motors, align the slots with the motor bolt pattern and break away the supports in the hinge pivot hole to expose the M3 nut pocket. Bolt the plate to the motor. Bolt the arm hinge to the plate snug, but not so tight that the bearings bind. (A dab of thread locker is a good idea.) Install the pinch gear on the motor shaft and confirm alignment with the idler. Insert spring. Compatible steppers:
Pretty much any common extruder stepper with a centered shaft and 22mm "pilot." Should include:
Any NEMA 17, geared or ungeared
Most NEMA 14s, geared or ungeared Compatible pinch gears:
Should work with pretty much anything from 9mm to 12mm diameter
Tested: TriDPrinting.com 8mm bore hardened pinch gear
Tested: Makerbot Mk7 gear
Tested: Random eBay mk8 gear
Tested: QU-BD Raptor Other hardware required:
3x 623 bearings
1x M3 screw 12-14mm long (idler bearing shaft)
1x M3 screw 20-25mm long (arm hinge, length depends on motor)
2-4x M3 screw 5-8mm long (motor mount)
2x M3 nuts
4-6x M3 washers recommended
1x spring approx 3/8" or 10mm diameter, ~25-30mm long (to compress to ~15mm in use)

comments.text: I've been using these for a while, and had to re-print one today that broke. Something I noticed this time: the arm, if printed upright as in the STL, does need supports in one spot if you want a perfect print: Take a look at the vertical hole through which the filament passes. Where the filament emerges from the arm to make contact with the gear and then goes back into the arm, there are un-supported horizontal overhangs on either side of the vertical hole where it re-enters above the bearing/gear.
comments.author: VanessaE

comments.text: Yeah, you're right. My assumption is that people will do a little cleanup with a hobby knife and ream out the filament path to size. That gives the tightest possible fit around the filament to avoid buckling with more flexible materials. If you print with 0.1mm layers, the mess there is minimal.

title: Raspberry Pi B+ LulzBot TAZ 4 Case/Extension

description.text: Based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:685585 but for Raspberry Pi B+. Because power usb connector located on a side, you will need to hack usb connector to fit between RPi and Fan. For power USB connector - I took laying around micro-USB cable with a long micro-USB side. Using pliers - folded tip 90 degrees. This broke plastic base and, most importantly - pulled pins away from the connector end. So I used angle-cutter to grind off extra :) Sounds super hackish, but it works :) As for getting power on RAMBO board - there is empty 5V source in the right bottom corner - see picture. Make sure to use correct polarity, as I believe incorrect one might damage RPi.

I wanted something a bit more low-profile, so I modified this spice rack design to fit my needs.  
This is perfect for those Tone's spices.  I wanted to be able to mount them in my cabinet door to be able to get them out of the way.  
In the end this design exceeded my expectations.  The spices are easy to access, and they slide right in.  
Feel free to adjust the settings for other sized spices.  You can modify the opening width, as well as make the spice rack taller if need be, or make the front lip taller as well.  
I left the screw holes in, but 3M 2-sided tape worked excellently for mounting.

Printed at 0.25mm layer height and 25% infill.  I used ABS.  
Used a 4mm brim to eliminate warping (10 turns @ 0.4mm nozzle in cura)  
The 5-wide model I had to print at a 45 degree angle to fit on my 200mm x 200mm bed.

description.text:
Beercan to cookpot conversion utilizes lids like these ( in metal) to keep out the creepy crawlies and to quicken the boil of water in the container; HIkers and backpackers have been using this configuration because its cheap and very lightweight. I've added a "sippy" type drink-dam and a whistle to alert you to a boil. The lid shown is a snap on version . It prints in two parts with the outer ring cone up and then glued with a lexan adhesive ( they should be printed in Nylon or Polycarbonate to withstand the heat). Alas, the snap on version will only work in the specific thread shown, it "might" fit other cans .. The last version just lays on top of pot and won't whistle unless held in place by screw ring, and then the center hole is usually filled by a silicone nub for a handle or a wooden knob to fit, the drink hole also must be plugged off
for the whistle to work. I will shortly upload a insert with a
mason jar thread that will slide into the cut beercan and then this lid will be held in place water tight with a regular mason jar ring...

author: tenzin_n

description.text:
I wanted tu bild a styrocube to make better photos of my 3d prints. For cheap. But I didnt want to have a big box (500x500x500 mm) eating up the space in my 3d printing room / home office / workshop so I wanted it to be detachable.   
Now after taking pictures I can just dissamble it by simply take the top and bottom off, and the parts uf the cube easily fit behind the rooms door. To set it up again just takes seconds.

print 12 of these hooks
measure the thickness of your styrofoam panels
mark the position of the hooks and make them stand over the edge just 1 mm smaller than the thickness og the panels is.
hotglue 6 hooks on the bottom plate, 2 hooks per side
do the same for the top plate.
now just put the side panels in the hooks, put the top panel on.
slide your background in.
done. for further information about the styrocube setups, just google for styrocube
w

Different parts for multicopters -
  • mm - motormounts
  • arm-250-structured printable structured arm for 250-size racing quadrocopters, it is compatible with ZMR250 carbon frame, or NUCLEUS or other ZMR250-compatible parts.
  • arm-250-structured4 - same, as previous, but for Emax MT2213 motors (Tyr001 request)
    • other parts will be added

File names:
mm-xxxxx-yy.. - motor mounts for motor xxxx and arm, made from various profiles - d12 - tube with diameter 12mm, d16 - tube with diameter 16mm, 10x10 - square profile 10x10 mm. W All parts was printed from ABS with 0.2 or 0.25 layer height, 4 top and bottom solid layers,40% fill. They have near the same weight - from 19 to 20 gramm. arm-250-structured - arm, zmr250 frame compatible. It has internal structure, so, don't print support . Material - ABS. Weight - 15g. Best results - with ABS, 0.34mm extruder, slic3r-stable, 0.2mm per layer, 3 layers for top, bottom, and perimeter, 15% fill density. Weight - 12g.

comments.text:
Came here to ask this. i recently did something like this for the gencon mascot. I make a high res mesh, then in edit mode selected random points twice and inverted the selection to have aproximately 25% of the points selected randomly, then alt-S scaled them out a little bit. Repeated the process and scaled them in. Then repeated the whole process in and out once again.
However this is a labor intensive method and would require starting with different polygoned meshed to get the different polygon counts. So I'm curious if that was the same method used here.

author: ottomyman

title: Side mounted fan duct for a rostock effector.

description.text:
My thermal break cold part is water cooled by a part I made myself but mywork piece fan cooling has been a bit poor with side fan only after I ditched my damaged previous hot end for an all metal replacement. Allow at least 40mm clearance from the underside of your effector to undersling this, that will give an air gap to flush the heat away from your print.   I should mention that I use swivel joints on my effector and carriages, mounted to the outside attachments, this won't work if you are using the standard universal joints and forked bars.  
Remember to shut your fan off for printing with nylon, PET-g etc.

The first version didn't give me quite enough bed clearance so I created the V2 one.  
I printed in nylon on my rostock with a 15 perimeter brim and 2mm layer height at 50mm/sec and 1.05mm wall thickness, 1mm top and bottom layer, 30% fill density and true 0.35mm nozzle orifice diameter with heated bed at 75deg C.  
I had to use Prits glue stick spread in croshatch pattern with a damp paper towel on the glass build plate and I placed small amounts of exterior PVA glue at the brim corners at around 2 layers high to arrest brim lift of the nylon. It took me several goes to get the nylon printing right. On my machine I had it up to 260 deg C but I suspect my temperature settings are higher than actual.

title: CNC mill 3D printed and laser cut

description.text:
Ive designed this mill so that most of the parts that are hard to get or make can be 3D printed. Its design to be modular so you can easily change the size of the machine by changing either the sides or the front and back plates. Its accurate enough to cut and drill circuit boards, and small enough to fit in the boot of your car.
Full instructions at http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-printed-CNC-mill/ I used an UP printer using ABS plastic, and there is a common problem with most printers is that they print holes around 1-2% undersize, so the the holes for the bearings, bolts and nut has been drawn little oversize to compensate. I cant predict how they will fit with other types of printers or materials. The sides and back are made with 2 layers of 3mm acrylic which can be laser cut if you have access to a laser cutter. Alternatively you could print the DXF files full size and cut and drill the material by hand.

http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-printed-CNC-mill/ The link has all the instruction you could wish for. There are 28 steps, if you cant see them all, click on the "view all steps" button directly below the the title.

title: GPS Case for Drotek Ublox NEO-M8N "XL"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a "small" case for the Drotek Ublox NEO-M8N "XL" measuring only
L x W x H: 53.5 x 53.5 x 16mm Design features:
-height of only 16mm
-holes for status LEDs
-access to USB port
-USB cable connects properly to USB port "clicks in"
-cables come out on the bottom Suitable for this GPS:
http://www.drotek.fr/shop/en/home/613-ublox-neo-m8n-gps-hmc5983-compass-xl.html

This case is designed with tight tolerances!
If your printer is not properly setup you will likely run into problems while printing. To screw the case together you will only need four Nylon Screws M3 x 6mm or M3 x 8mm. The Mounting holes in the top part are already the right core diameter for cutting M3.
You can cut the threads with a M3 tap or by screwing a regular M3 Steel screw in and out several times.
I tried both methods and they work fine. My settings for this print: initial layer height: 0.06mm
initial layer speed 15mm/s
layer height: 0.15mm
print speed: 35mm/s
infill: 25%
shell thickness: 0.8mm
bottom/top thickness: 0.75mm

author: depri51giu

description.text: YARC! - Yet Another Raspberry Case there are many options for a raspberry pi case on thingiverse - but none quite covered all the features I was looking for... so time to design one :-)

Updates
2015-03-25 added top with groove for CSI ribbon cable and another with CSI+GPIO

there are variants:
for M2.5 screws
completly screw-less snap-together

this case tries to be:
  • slender and snugly fitting around the pi
  • low profile/height
  • not bulky: walls are as thin as possible, but as thick as necessary to be sturdy enough
  • closed, to keep dust out (the pi doesn't run that hot anyway...)
  • two parts - lower part acting as coaster
  • assembled with readily available parts: easy to come by M3 screws
  • easy to disassemble - using the mounting holes with easy to come by M3 screws (countersunk M3x16mm) and set-in M3 nuts
  • not occlude the status leds
  • printable without any support structures
Note: this requires the "mounting" holes to be widened to accommodate the bigger screw - which the raspberry foundation discourages since it might damage the pcb!

M3x16 countersunk screws where used (3mm diameter, 16mm long)
the corresponding nuts can be either press-fitted into their holes - or if you find the holes slightly to tight: heat-set into them (no-tools version: put the nut on a screw and heat it up over a candle/lighter-flame)
what worked for me was was mount a 3mm drill in a cuck and carfully drill out the hole by hand - to not damage/stress the pcb
filling the led-"hole" with hot-meld adhesive or clear silicone-caulk as diffuser works great

author: sharkbot

description.text:
A spaghetti portion Hopper. Put dry spaghetti in the top hopper. Then turn the knob on the side to dispense roughly a 1" portion (1 person portion) of spaghetti into the tray. This should be printed with any plastic that can be considered Food Safe as it will be contact with the printed plastic.  
Some gluing will be needed but, the glue points are designed to be on the outside surfaces only. See the Instructions for what to do. I will upload a Thumbnail when I get a chance. The computer I'm currently using doesn't support uploading images.

Print: (1) Left Wall
(1) Right Wall
(2) Hopper wo-tray
(2) Hopper w-tray
(1) Spindle w-handle
(1) spindle wo-handle
(2) Lid Halfs
(3) Link 1.) Slide One Hopper wo-tray into the Left wall. The round part of the Hopper pieces will slide into the inside of the curved Tab on the wall pieces. The upper Tabs will be to the inside of the Hopper Wall. Press the flat wall of the Hopper wo-tray piece against the flat upper tab on the wall. Apply a small line of glue to the inside edge of the curved tab on the wall which should apply glue to the outside contact edge of the hopper. 2.) Now take One Hopper w-tray and and repeat the process. Note this piece will have sit on the two lower tabs in the wall piece. Apply glue to these tabs as well on the outside only.. 3.) Take the Right wall and repeat steps 1 and 2 for the other two Hopper pieces. 4.) Take the Spindle wo-Handle and slide it into the now round spot between the hopper pieces on the Left wall. Note: the triangular stub should be facing out. 5.) Take the Spindle w-handle and slit is into the round spot between the hopper pieces on the Right Wall. Note: The Round Stub should fit into the round hole in the Right Wall. 6.) Match the two assembled half's together. Now take two of the Link pieces. The stubs on the Link parts should fit into the indentations on the Hopper Pieces. You will want to glue the two top Link Pieces in place by putting some glue in the indentation as well as run a bead of glue around the edge of the Link piece. 7.) The third Link piece goes into the nubs on the bottom of the tray part of the Hopper w-tray piece. This part has holes and not indents so do not put glue on the inside of the holes. Only apply glue to the outside edge of the Link piece to lock it to the two halves. 8.) Wait for the Glue to dry and you should be good to go. Fill the hopper with Spaghetti and place the two lid halves onto. Note the hopper should be roughly 11 3/4" in length which should fit most box spaghetti you get from the store as they are 10-12 inches in length on average. For every half a turn of the Knob, you should get one portion of spaghetti. One full Turn should be two portions, etc.

Just a few cabinet Knobs. There's the standard Knob, A Fleur-de-lis knob, a Rose shapped knob, a rose handle and a Fleur-de-lis handle. The no4 MS Screw Cover is only needed for the Fleur-de-lis handle.  
All the knobs should work for #6 hadware except for the Fleur-de-lis handle, which should use #4 hardware.

Hey, this is a spider. This was a gift to my son's friend.
Numbers in stl files represent the pieces req'ed to make a complete spider.
Made with the new Diamond Nozzle capable of printing 3 colors through a single nozzle from www.reprap.me

Opened the ring base in Netfabb Basic and cut it into several pieces, saved them as individual stl files, recombined every other using Slic3r 1.1.7 and saved as a stl file, did the same for every odd piece and saved as another stl file.
Then used the "Combine multi-material STL files..." function to recombine everything into a single AMF file ready for you to download and print

title: Stone Age Kitchen Towel Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bring a piece of ancient history into your kitchen by printing this authentic stone age towel holder ;-) If you are looking for a simpler, smaller design, have a look at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:706767 as well!
But if you like cartoons, silly contraptions and don't mind sacrificing a few pen springs (see instructions), you know which one I'm gonna recommend...

The design prints in 4 parts (unfortunately, I couldn't think of a way to make it completely support-free for the larger parts) and won't need much assembly. In order to change towel rolls, you need to be able to pull the axis pieces apart. I suggest you mirror the STL so that the rather bulky-looking moving part faces away from the room...unless you really like that look. Find two springs (e.g. from old pens) that are about 20x1.5 mm - the typical size of springs I found in my pens and therefor the one I used when modeling. Next, stick these springs into the long holes in the smallest part (red piece on the far right in the renderings) and make sure the won't come out of the side. If they do, you should still be able to get this part to function by using a large washer when you mount it on the wall, thereby covering most of the spring channels.
IMPORTANT - before you mount the moving part to the wall, make sure the distance to the other part and the length of the springs allow an easy exchange of rolls while maintaining stability in the relaxed state - you may need someone to help you with holding everything in place. If the springs are too strong, cut a piece off and stretch the remainder back to the required length. Now mount everything on the wall, again checking the ease of movement from time to time and especially before tightening the last screws.

A case for a RPi A+, B+ or B2 in the shape of an amiga 500.
This is based on Falken76's Amiga 500 model http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67140 but has been stretched so as to fit a pi nicely without having to print an oversized case.
  • The old Top piece wasn't slicing correctly in slic3r and has now been fixed with netfabb. The part is now a smaller file size and will slice properly
  • A new bottom part has been uploaded with a cutout for access to the SD slot
    • I have not yet printed one myself so is a WIP. There will likely need to be support material whichever way it's printed and it may not even fit a real Pi There has been one known successful print of this and the top will require support materiel to be generated. from my slicing, it seems printing it upside-down uses the least support and quickest time
Has not been made yet. There is a thin panel in the disk drive opening which is meant to provide support and be knocked out for passing GPIO cables through.

description.text:
Projet d'impression 3d d'un Sabot de flash. Yves Le Chevalier Ce projet est un support de flash esclave (flash Nikon pour moi) mais convient à tout autre flash pour un usage strobist (coldshoe)
Il peut aussi servir de support à tout appareil (sauf des reflex trop lourds) pour des photos avec retardateur (usage en selfies). http://yveslechevalier.free.fr

Ce projet se compose :
  • d'une pince à 2€ (magasin de bricolage) dont on remplace l'axe par un écrou,
  • d'une rotule de récupération montée avec une tige filetée au 1/4 de pouce (standard photo)
  • d'un sabot en matiere plastique (ABS) à imprimer en 3D.
    L'usage d'un sabot isolant évite les courts circuits des sabots métalliques.
    Les flash Nikon peuvent être verrouillés sur le sabot (petit trou) mais tous les flash peuvent être montés sur le sabot.

author: AwesomeA

description.text:
!!!NOTICE: There is now a new version of my lizard which has a fix for a problem with his eyes.  Please let me know if you experience any issues with this file.  
This little chap is my first model of a living creature. I built him in Blender 2.66a (the release I have has a 3D prinitng toolbox which I believe is still in testing but worth looking at regardless). He is not any particular kind of lizard and I have tried to make him look as sweet as possible for a reptile! If you look closely, he is smiling at you:-)

He renders without error in OpenSCAD. He does not need supports and his base is nice and flat so you should be good to go. He prints well in ABS and PLA. The shiny red lizard was printed in ABS
The plain red lizard was printed in ABS
The greeny yellow lizard was printed using a heat reactive ABS
The black lizard was printed in PLA The greeny yellow and the shiny red lizard were 'steamed' in acetone to make them shine.

comments.text:
Post pictures!:-)
Regarding your other issues: a 'dribbly' lizard chin is usually down to insufficient cooling or the feedrate for your filament is set too high. You could try adjusting those.
His shoulders are supposed to look like that (although I admit the overhang is too harsh and they have a tendency to collapse). Lizards have these strange folds above their shoulders that look like 80s shoulder pads:-)

author: SimonFront

title: Daily earring #1: FH-Kiel logo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello there. I present you my collections of ...
DAILY EARRINGS! (See all at http://www.thingiverse.com/tag:Daily_earrings ) Yep. I bought myself a 3D printer (FDM) and then thought to myself, that it would be a nice idea to make some earrings for my girlfriend.
I was so happy about how the machine manages to print such small things that I designed another, and another, and another...
Now I am close to 60 earrings which almost all printed fine. Why am I doing this?
  • To test how small I can go with the printer
  • The little prints allow me to try lots of stuff without wasting much time and material
  • It increases the WAF ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wife_acceptance_factor )
  • 3D printing + Gifts = Love!
    • Some are simple, some are original work I have spend a few hours on, and some are devirates- depending on how much time and ideas I had.
    My girlfriend is into a lot of things, such as computers, video games, star treck, so expect rather random things. As I am making these on a daily basis, please excuse the sloppy files. I usualy just turn an idea into a earring with sketchup, and they are hardly ever manifold. That's why I am providing the source SKP files as well, so you can edit, modify and remove the ring if you wish. Unless otherwise noted, these are original work.
    you may have seen these designs on my site http://www.wap.cc or RingOhr.de, and I now decided to share them with you. Enjoy.
    You may use them for your projects, as long as they are non-commercial (otherwise, ask me for permission). That means deverates have to include be for NC use only as well. If I see these files on Shapeways or similar without having been asked first: Great, you did it! I won't share them anymore. So you forgot your girl's birthday, valentines, christmas, wedding aniversary?
    Or you need a toy thing for your kid?
    PRINT! What you will need: 1) A 3D printer (d'oh)
    I am from the dark side of 3D printing... using a commercial pp3dp.com "UP!" plus.
    So you might want to print them larger and/or add some support manualy. Just don't ask, I probably won't even remember what UP settings I used ;-)
    Even with an UP some things are fragil and horrible to clean, as I am constantly trying what is possible to print and what is not. 2) Stuff! 2mm and 5mm rhinestones never hurt, or wedding decoration diamonds. And Magnets. 1.5x3mm discs work great. Keep an eye on my work as there's more stuff with those soon... 3) Coloring:
    You probably noticed that I colored them. Nail polish works great as it bonds to the ABS and is rather cheap.
    If you want to search for it at ebay, search for:
    (nail polish,nailpolish,nagellack) 72
    72 colors (11ml) should be available for under 30â‚¬/$40 incl. shipping. Other sets of this cheap stuff seems to be available as well (12/24/48), but in the large set you have all colors in metallic, glitter and regular.
    I was sceptical at first, but it works great and glitter is great for lasers. And lasers are manly. Ergo, nail polish is manly. Buy it. Note: Sorry for some bad pictures... Macro photos with flash usualy reveal every bump and error. The real things at "eye resolution" of the daily earrings look much nicer. THIS IS DAILY EARRING #1:
    Logo of http://FH-Kiel.de It's our universities logo as earring. Expect more interesting stuff soon as this was the first print. All rights for the logo belong to the FH-Kiel, but I guess some students might find it usefull. NOTE: Some models may need rescaling (0.03937) due to export-import settings where accedentally set to inches. I have been asked if she actually wears all of them. The answer is yes. Almost all of them.
Print- pretty easy on this one. I made the backside hollow so it is lighter and easier to remove from the raft (as I had initial problems with the rafts but it's all fixed now).

description.text:
This app allows users to be able to turn images into printable 3D Objects.  It generates a height map as a relief of the image, coded in OpenSCAD file which can then be furthered customized using the Thingiverse Customizer.  Advanced and experienced users can custom tailor the output by using the OpenSCAD app and modifying the code by further manipulating the image data.   
We hope to make it available on the Apple Appstore shortly - for free.  
We want to thank Makerbot for the opportunity to participate in this first Makerbot Thingiverse Hackathon.  
The PixSCAD Team

comments.text: Seriously cool little app, guys! It's really neat to have an iPhone app that writes OpenSCAD and uploads it to Thingiverse directly!
comments.author: laird

comments.text:
Hi dyldog,
This is a simple app that looks at the pixels in an image and generates a height map based on the color values. The data is made part of the OpenSCAD file so users that are familiar with OpenSCAD can derive a great variation of the same file. Users who are not familiar with OpenSCAD can still change some parameters through the customizer once they upload their generated OpenSCAD file to Thingiverse and flag them with customizer.

description.text: I purchased a car charger for my Nokia 920 from Europe for about $100.00 ( I live in the U.S.).  The part in inside that clamps the sides of the phone in place broke after about a month.  I designed this piece to replace it.

comments.text: STL is uploaded with wrong size.  It's too small. Proper size should be 27.5mm x 12mm.
comments.author: Irek

comments.text: STL files do not contain a definition of unit of measure (inch,mm,cm).  It is common for a file made in a particular unit of measure to not load properly into another app that is set to a different unit size.  A common fix is to enlarge reduce the object by a factor of 10 (mm to cm) or 25.4 (mm to inch) or 2.54 (cm to inch). See if one of these factors gives you the size you are expecting.
comments.author: Irek

My clip broke within a week, so I drew up a new one.

comments.text: I print it standing up on the left or right edge, so the pin holes point straight up.  That gives the most strength against the forces that are placed on the hinge.  Udes this for over a year and it never broke using simple PLA plastic.

Something I made to dispense food for my degus. I'm working towards a operant-conditioning-chamber type of toy for them to play with while I'm away during the day. This is the feeder module for that system. As I finish them, I'll be posting the "display" module (row of LEDs with two-button input) and the controller code. In the end, I want to make some simple puzzles/games for the degus to work through. I added an agitator stick to keep the food from jamming in the hopper. It seems to work pretty well for small granular food that doesn't pack. See video: http://youtu.be/GxMIHgMNGUo

Just print all the parts and fit them together.  
You will need to drill holes for the servo horn attachment screws on the underside of the wheel part, and one hole on top of the wheel part for the agitator stick.   
It is easiest to put the agitator stick through the fulcrum, then clip it on to the hopper.

comments.text: You should include a video/picture with your degus! If I created anything like this our degus would just chew it to shreds.
comments.author: agweber
